data.body: If the code to do this is short I think it could be nice to include in the lib itself. But [seems like it's not](https://github.com/GuyGood/three.js/blob/AngleBasedSmoothing/src/extras/GeometryUtils.js#L6-L152).

No, it is a lot ot stuff, because of going through all of the faces and all the extras. I think there could be some optimizations, but i dont think it can be done with less than 100 lines, if at all. atm it is 290 lines _cough_ in length.

What you should think about is that this code also replaces computeVertexNormals as you could enter 180° angle and have everything smoothed. I compared two completely smoothed cubes and they look the same! computeVertexNormals is 150 lines of code, too ;) 

The thing is, that as Three.js is web-based i think that many people are going to create Meshes dynamically and this function would be a great addition, esspecially if you have shapes with holes and all of this. 

Anyway, i just wanted to show this and thought it would be useful to many users :)

hmm, so 20 days later? :) 
maybe anyone else has some comments about the code or how to shorten it a bit?

@mrdoob 
Well, what do you think, i mean by removing the original computeVertexNormals because my "new" code can do the same and one could apply a shortcut if the user wants totally smoothed stuff.

So you remove the old computeVertexNormals which is 150 lines and the new stuff would only add 200 new lines, which i don't think is a lot. Anyway, just wanted to hear your final judgement because i would remove the online code if no one is interested.
An alternative solution for custom geometries is to duplicate vertices on hard edges (and, if desired, on seams). In that case, `Geometry.computeVertexNormals()` should be OK as is.

Hey WestLangley, cool that you are joining in. 
Does your answer imply that you, too, don't see a necessity for angle based vertex normal smoothing and would opt for another approach but whatever it is, not include it in three.js? 
Because as you proposed, a user would have to somehow find seams/hard edges and then duplicate those specific vertices? :)

three.js is primarily a rendering library, not a modeling library, and as such, does not have sophisticated modeling tools. It is up to @mrdoob to decide if he want to include features like the one you proposed.

I think it would be great if you kept your utility available on github for others to use. I have seen this feature requested in the past.

ok. Well, my main points of thought were that as three.js is web-based, 1) there could often be dynamically created content and 2) it influences the display of content, so it is definetly connected to rendering.

Anyway, may I ask you 1 question:  How deep did you check my code or read my explanation? Do you think one could shorten the source code or optimize it? Anyway, just a question :) Thanks for participating in this at all :)

hey zz85, great to have a response at all :)  
warning: sorry, long reply :D 

> "how well does it apply to other different kind of geometries?" 

Well, i did not test a lot, yet. Mainly because I wanted to know if this feature is wanted at all and for my use case works. I am generating some kind of steel plate with holes and bevel and the smoothing looks pretty good so that i am fine with it. The circle shape in the screenshot was just for showing the audience, so to say :) I am not sure if there is any kind of geometry edge case that would not work except of course for those geometries where an angle-weighted approach is not useful. What i can think of is deformed planeGeometries that i have not tested yet but i think they should smooth too as the user wants. 

> "does the angle need to be selected intelligently"

Definitely. It all depends on the bevelling parameters or whatever the user generated or what look he/she wants to achieve. 

> also, do you have any links to reference on the approach you or others have implemented here?

No, unfortunately not. I found a gamedev-thread which i don't have at hand right now but the people all had some different ideas and I was just implementing a stupid straight forward approach which seems to work but is not quite tested and maybe has some edge case problems. I also posted here because I thought you guys would give me some input too about what you think how it can be done or done faster. 

I will search some more stuff, for example i found this one:

http://docs.autodesk.com/3DSMAX/15/ENU/3ds-Max-SDK-Programmer-Guide/index.html?url=files/GUID-0FCB4578-77F8-4F05-99CD-349E85F13639.htm,topicNumber=d30e22921

But i did not have the time to go into more detail as the problem is not quite that easy after a second look. 
You can divide the problem in two parts: 

1) One would have to check for faster ways (or shorter to program ways) to find adjacent faces/edges. 
2) Maybe there is even a better way to generate those "smoothing groups".

Well, I thought if mrDoob or others liked the feature, they would chime in or give tips about how to find and cache adjacent faces/edges and so on but I am willing to do this, too!! Right now i am fine but i would love to shorten the code with some nice math and  javascript  magic and i would invest more time in finding papers on this problem!

> lastly, if computeVertexNormals is replaced with your function, how much penalty in performance 

Yes, it does a lot more calculus and you can't do this in the render loop but why wouldn't you at all. I measured around 30ms on an old core2 duo desktop CPU and for the first run a bit more ( i guess the browser does some caching here and there). Although i already changed the functions a bit and moved some variable declaration stuff outside of some loops which seemed to help improve performance. 

Anyway, as the area weighted averaging is taken from the now-used computeVertexNormals function, one could write a really short bypass via a boolean flag if no angle is provided for example and just iterate over all faces the way it is done now. Then, performance would be the same as it is now and the results are the same, too.

I stumbled on this issue today, as I was looking to use the creaseAngle property from a VRML IndexedFaceSet to attain a smoothed curved surface. From what I have found so far, I can only choose between smooth nothing and smooth everything, am I right @mrdoob @WestLangley ? Both solutions (everything and nothing smoothed) look horrible in this particular use case (a bent shape with holes in it).

@bartmcleod The constant `THREE.SmoothShading` was poorly-named. See the discussion in #10383.

You need to fix your geometry. Duplicate vertices on hard edges and specify proper vertex normals for each vertex.

For anyone who finds this with the same question: A small test shows that with duplicate edges, it works just fine when calling only `computeVertexNormals()` to generate the normals automatically. Of course this does not respect any specific creaseAngle, just some default angle. Make sure not to call `mergeVertices()`, because this will get rid of any duplicate vertices you created to cater for the duplicate edges. Like I said, this was in a small test, with only three square faces in an IndexedFaceSet, which will result in 6 faces after parsing the original VRML.
@GuyGood The image you linked too no longer exists in that location.
@bartmcleod Sorry, this is not the proper forum for help. Perhaps you can try stackoverflow.
Yeah, ok.

bart, 

What are you looking for? If you can edit the normals of your VRML object in a dedicated Digital Content Creation Software like Blender/3dsMax/Maya whatever, then you should do so. 

If you cant, you can try out the method that I wrote from my fork. Or does this not work anymore? I havn't been using ThreeJS for a long long time. Concerning the image, i don't know what it displayed. I could only guess, sorry. But it was for sure some kind of bevel on a cylinder that was correctly smoothed.  Like this: http://imgur.com/a/APXgh

GuyGood, how nice of you to respond on such an old issue. 

I have now picked up this thread on Stackoverflow to discuss my issue further, as it might turn out to be just a need for help: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27055644/three-js-maintaining-creases-when-smooth-shading-custom-geometry

I think the simplest use case that describes my problem is  a Cylinder with computeVertexNormals(). It does not appear to have sharp edges. The top and bottom seem to bulge outward. I understand that it comes from averaging the vertexnormals, which makes sense. What I do not understand is that a default cylinder does not have the necessary duplicated edges to support computeVertexNormals() in a way that produces an expected result.

The same holds true for a standard cube. It also does not seem to have sharp edges and it lights up in a weird way, to say the least. I am getting even more confused, if I build a cube as an IndexedFaceSet, with duplicated edges where necessary (based on creaseAngle). It renders very similar if not identical to a default Cube. Also, a vague line is visible where the triangles are co-planar and should be completely smoothed out.

Of course, I can be totally wrong on all of theses topics, if I missed a point somewhere. I would be happy to try out your code by the way.

👍 for the original suggestion of @GuyGood to have a way so smooth out areas based on a crease angle. I have written code now that can duplicate edges if the angle between two face normals is larger than a given crease angle, to keep that angle sharp, as @WestLangley suggested. This works well, but there is an impact on load time. I'm currently working on making this independent on how the geometry is loaded. The solution I have only works on triangulated faces currently, not on polygons.

Hello everyone,
I am finding myself in the same situation. @bartmcleod , can you please share such code with us? It could be a great help to those of us who don't care that much about loading time, but do care about proper rendering.
Thank you!
Hi @danidr, the code is in the VrmlParser repository on GitHub. If I can find the time, I will lookup the exact bits for you.

I guess it's this whole bit?
[EdgeDuplicator](https://github.com/bartmcleod/VrmlParser/blob/master/Renderer/ThreeJs/EdgeDuplicator.js)
Will test it later and report if it works with latest ThreeJS. Thank you again in the meanwhile!

>I think the simplest use case that describes my problem is a Cylinder with computeVertexNormals(). It does not appear to have sharp edges. The top and bottom seem to bulge outward. I understand that it comes from averaging the vertexnormals, which makes sense. What I do not understand is that a default cylinder does not have the necessary duplicated edges to support computeVertexNormals() in a way that produces an expected result.

FWIW, `CylinderBufferGeometry` will do what you expect -- except on the seam where the sides wrap around, meet, and vertices are not shared. `BoxBufferGeometry` will work as you expect, too.

@WestLangley thank you, that might prove to be a really helpful tip. Why does the `CylinderBufferGeometry` have a seam? It can't be that hard to share the vertices of the last triangle with the first... @danidr Yes, that would be EdgeDuplicator. If I recall correctly, it only works on IndexedFacedSet, not on standard geometries, such as a cylinder or a sphere, but you may find that their buffered counterparts work well for you, as West pointed out.

>Why does the CylinderBufferGeometry have a seam?

Because the UVs are not continuous there, so the vertices need to be duplicated.

Hello everyone! 
I found a solution just by modifying the exist `computeVertexNormals()`
Live example: https://codepen.io/Ni55aN/pen/zROmoe?editors=0010
Source code: https://gist.github.com/Ni55aN/90c017fafbefd3e31ef8d98ab6566cfa
@Ni55aN Looking good! How does it behave with other shapes?

@bartmcleod I have not tested with a lot of shapes yet. One shape after CSG processing looks correct, but small transitions between neighboring faces are visible (perhaps just because of the geometry)
